title: Blog

Blog
Welcome to my clinical programming blog.

title: Agile Methodologies
text:
Agile in Clinical Programming
As the clinical programming industry evolves, the need for agility grows stronger. Traditional waterfall models are being replaced with Scrum-inspired approaches, where cross-functional teams collaborate continuously.

Sprint-based programming (TFL production in cycles).
Early validation and continuous feedback.
Collaboration between data management, programming, and biostatistics.

This section will grow as I continue exploring and applying Agile methodologies in clinical programming.

title: About Me
text:
About Me
My journey started in Electronic Engineering, but I soon realized I wanted to work closer to the healthcare field. That’s how I transitioned into Biomedical Engineering, combining technology with a passion for health.
From the beginning, my work always revolved around data analysis — first in hardware (processor data), then in business intelligence, and finally in clinical trials. This constant evolution helped me develop both technical programming skills and a strong sense of how data can tell the story of a product’s development.
What truly inspires me is seeing how clinical trial data reflects the real-world impact a treatment can have — from initial data cleaning and reporting, to seeing that product eventually reach the market and help thousands of people.

Every dataset is a story of lives transformed — and I’m proud to help write those stories.

title: Migrating from SAS to R in Clinical Programming
Migrating from SAS to R in Clinical Programming
Migrating from SAS to R in Clinical Programming
Survival Analysis in R
text:
This project demonstrates Kaplan-Meier estimation using survival and ggplot2 in R.


library(survival)
library(ggplot2)

km_fit <- survfit(Surv(AVAL, CNSR) ~ TRTP, data = adtte)
ggsurvplot(km_fit)



Survival analysis is a key analysis in oncology trials, especially for endpoint analysis like Progression-Free Survival (PFS) and Overall Survival (OS).

title: Survival Analysis in R
